info.name: ConservOcean API
info.description: This API's endpoints are seperated into 3 sections: fish, bodies of water, and human impacts.

item.name: Fish

exec: pm.test("Check Keys in Response Body", function () {
pm.test("Check Data in Response Body", function () {

query.description: Maximum number of fish to return
Which index to start querying from

request.description: Returns all the fish instances avaliable. You can specify the limit (the maximum number to return) and offset (the index to start query from) query parameters to refine the return. If no limit or offset defined then return all of the fish instances.

response.name: Get all Fish

query.description: Maximum number of fish to return
Which index to start querying from

response.body:
{
    "total_fish_count": 1301,
    "total_fish_returned": 2,
    "data": [
        {
            "id": 1,
            "scientific_name": "Ablennes hians",
            "common_name": "Flat needlefish",
            "species": "hians",
            "genus": "Ablennes",
            "family": "No Family",
            "habitat": "0 -1 -1",
            "endanger_status": "LC",
            "population_trend": "Unknown",
            "average_size": 140,
            "picture_url": "https://www.fishbase.de/images/species/Abhia_m0.jpg",
            "description": "Inhabits neritic and oceanic waters but more often found near islands (Ref. 5213).  Found in estuaries (Ref. 26340), and coastal rivers (Ref. 33587).  Sometimes forming large schools (Ref. 5217).  Feeds mainly on small fishes (Ref. 9279).  Oviparous (Ref. 205).  Eggs may be found attached to objects in the water by filaments on the egg's surface (Ref. 205). Since the jaws are frequently broken, the maximum length is given as body length excluding head and caudal fin.  Usually caught with the help of artificial lights (Ref. 9279).  Marketed  fresh and salted; smoked or frozen (Ref. 9987).  Market limited due to the green-colored flesh (Ref. 5217).  In females, only left gonad is developed, and in males the right gonad is small or absent (Ref. 26938).",
            "speccode": 972,
            "catch_year": "2018",
            "catch_rate": 22,
            "model": "fish"
        },
        {
            "id": 2,
            "scientific_name": "Abudefduf abdominalis",
            "common_name": "Green damselfish",
            "species": "abdominalis",
            "genus": "Abudefduf",
            "family": "Pomacentrinae",
            "habitat": "0 0 -1",
            "endanger_status": "LC",
            "population_trend": "Stable",
            "average_size": 30,
            "picture_url": "https://www.fishbase.de/images/species/Ababd_u0.jpg",
            "description": "Found in quiet waters with rocky bottoms in inshore and offshore reefs; juveniles sometimes found in surge pools (Ref. 205).  Benthopelagic (Ref. 58302).  Adults form school.  Feed on a variety of algae and zooplankton.  Oviparous, distinct pairing during breeding (Ref. 205).  Eggs are demersal and adhere to the substrate (Ref. 205).  Males guard and aerate the eggs (Ref. 205).  Used as food by the Hawaiians (Ref. 7364).",
            "speccode": 6652,
            "catch_year": null,
            "catch_rate": null,
            "model": "fish"
        }
    ]
}

variable.description: Id of the specific fish you want to return

request.description:
Get a fish by the specified ID passed into with the id path parameter.

The response body includes the ids of all of th related instances from other models.

response.name: Get Fish By Id

variable.description: Id of the specific fish you want to return

Sometimes forming large schools (Ref. 5217).  Feeds mainly on small fishes (Ref. 9279).  Oviparous (Ref. 205).  Eggs may be found attached to objects in the water by filaments on the egg's surface (Ref. 205). Since the jaws are frequently broken, the maximum length is given as body length excluding head and caudal fin.  Usually caught with the help of artificial lights (Ref. 9279). exec: pm.test("Check Data in Response Body", function () {
pm.test("Check Data in Response Body", function () {

query.description: The IUCN category status to query fish for.

request.description:
Returns all the fish that have the status of one of the below categories passed in with the status query parameter.

IUCN Red List Categories available at this link: https://iucn-csg.org/red-list-categories/

EXTINCT (EX)
EXTINCT IN THE WILD (EW)
CRITICALLY ENDANGERED (CR)
ENDANGERED (EN)
VULNERABLE (VU)
NEAR THREATENED (NT)
LEAST CONCERN (LC)
DATA DEFICIENT (DD)
NOT EVALUATED (NE)

response.name: Get Fish By Endangered Status

query.description: The IUCN category status to query fish for.

response.body: { "total_fish_count": 1301, "total_fish_returned": 10, "data": [ { "id": 1, "scientific_name": "Ablennes hians", "common_name": "Flat needlefish", "species": "hians", "genus": "Ablennes", "family": "No Family", "habitat": "0 -1 -1", "endanger_status": "LC", "population_trend": "Unknown", "average_size": 140, "picture_url": "https://www.fishbase.de/images/species/Abhia_m0.jpg", "description": "Inhabits neritic and oceanic waters but more often found near islands (Ref. 5213). Found in estuaries (Ref. 26340), and coastal rivers (Ref. 33587). Sometimes forming large schools (Ref. 5217). Feeds mainly on small fishes (Ref. 9279). Oviparous (Ref. 205). Eggs may be found attached to objects in the water by filaments on the egg's surface (Ref. 205). Since the jaws are frequently broken, the maximum length is given as body length excluding head and caudal fin. Usually caught with the help of artificial lights (Ref. 9279). Marketed fresh and salted; smoked or frozen (Ref. 9987). Market limited due to the green-colored flesh (Ref. 5217). In females, only left gonad is developed, and in males the right gonad is small or absent (Ref. 26938).", "speccode": 972, "catch_year": "2018", "catch_rate": 22, "model": "fish" }, { "id": 2, "scientific_name": "Abudefduf abdominalis", "common_name": "Green damselfish", "species": "abdominalis", "genus": "Abudefduf", "family": "Pomacentrinae", "habitat": "0 0 -1", "endanger_status": "LC", "population_trend": "Stable", "average_size": 30, "picture_url": "https://www.fishbase.de/images/species/Ababd_u0.jpg", "description": "Found in quiet waters with rocky bottoms in inshore and offshore reefs; juveniles sometimes found in surge pools (Ref. 205). Benthopelagic (Ref. 58302). Adults form school. Feed on a variety of algae and zooplankton. Oviparous, distinct pairing during breeding (Ref. 205). Eggs are demersal and adhere to the substrate (Ref. 205). Males guard and aerate the eggs (Ref. 205). Used as food by the Hawaiians (Ref. 7364).", "speccode": 6652, "catch_year": null, "catch_rate": null, "model": "fish" }, { "id": 3, "scientific_name": "Abudefduf lorenzi", "common_name": "Black-tail sergeant", "species": "lorenzi", "genus": "Abudefduf", "family": "Pomacentrinae", "habitat": "0 0 -1", "endanger_status": "LC", "population_trend": "Stable", "average_size": 18, "picture_url": "https://www.fishbase.de/images/species/Ablor_u2.jpg", "description": "Adults inhabit protected coastal areas often around docks or breakwaters (Ref. 7247). Often found in loose aggregations or widely scattered individuals near or along shorelines (Ref. 90102). Oviparous, distinct pairing during breeding (Ref. 205). Eggs are demersal and adhere to the substrate (Ref. 205). Males guard and aerate the eggs (Ref. 205).", "speccode": 5685, "catch_year": null, "catch_rate": null, "model": "fish" }, { "id": 4, "scientific_name": "Abudefduf notatus", "common_name": "Yellowtail sergeant", "species": "notatus", "genus": "Abudefduf", "family": "Pomacentrinae", "habitat": "0 0 -1", "endanger_status": "LC", "population_trend": "Stable", "average_size": 17, "picture_url": "https://www.fishbase.de/images/species/Abnot_u4.jpg", "description": "Found in small groups along upper edges of sheltered drop-offs. Also found in rocky inshore reefs with moderate to strong wave action. In roving aggregations and somewhat difficult to approach (Ref. 9710). Oviparous, distinct pairing during breeding (Ref. 205). Eggs are demersal and adhere to the substrate (Ref. 205). Males guard and aerate the eggs (Ref. 205).", "speccode": 5686, "catch_year": null, "catch_rate": null, "model": "fish" }, { "id": 5, "scientific_name": "Abudefduf saxatilis", "common_name": "Sergeant-major", "species": "saxatilis", "genus": "Abudefduf", "family": "Pomacentrinae", "habitat": "0 0 -1", "endanger_status": "LC", "population_trend": "Stable", "average_size": 23, "picture_url": "https://www.fishbase.de/images/species/Absax_u7.jpg", "description": "Juveniles are common in tide pools while adults are found over shallow reef tops. Adults frequently form large feeding aggregations of up to several hundred individuals. Food items include algae, small crustaceans and fish, and various invertebrate larvae (Ref. 3139). At Fernando de Noronha Archipelago, this species feeds on spinner dolphins’ feces and vomits. The offal feeding may be regarded as a simple behavioral shift from plankton feeding to drifting offal picking. Also, juveniles may hold cleaning stations together with the doctorfish (Acanthurus chirurgus) and the blue tang (Acanthurus coeruleus) and graze algae as well as pick molted skin and parasites from green turtles (Chelonia mydas ). This behavior is preceded by a characteristic inspection usually followed by feeding nips on the turtles’ skin (head, limbs, and tail), as well as on the carapace. The most inspected and cleaned body parts are the flippers (Ref. 48727, 51385). Adult males adopt a bluish ground color when guarding eggs. Oviparous, distinct pairing during breeding (Ref. 205). Eggs are demersal and adhere to the substrate (Ref. 205). Attracted to divers who feed fish. Marketed fresh (Ref. 3139). Has been reared in captivity (Ref. 35420).", "speccode": 1119, "catch_year": null, "catch_rate": null, "model": "fish" }, { "id": 6, "scientific_name": "Abudefduf sexfasciatus", "common_name": "Scissortail sergeant", "species": "sexfasciatus", "genus": "Abudefduf", "family": "Pomacentrinae", "habitat": "0 0 -1", "endanger_status": "LC", "population_trend": "Stable", "average_size": 19, "picture_url": "https://www.fishbase.de/images/species/Absex_u0.jpg", "description": "Adults inhabit inshore and offshore coral or rocky reefs. Also in shallow coastal reef flats or crests, usually where lots of tall soft corals or hydroid colonies are present (Ref. 48636). Often found in groups feeding at midwater or tending nests among rocks and coral ledges (Ref. 90102). Feed on zooplankton and algae and aggregates high in the water column (Ref. 9710). Oviparous, distinct pairing during breeding (Ref. 205). Eggs are demersal and adhere to the substrate (Ref. 205). Males guard and aerate the eggs (Ref. 205).", "speccode": 5688, "catch_year": null, "catch_rate": null, "model": "fish" }, { "id": 7, "scientific_name": "Abudefduf sordidus", "common_name": "Blackspot sergeant", "species": "sordidus", "genus": "Abudefduf", "family": "Pomacentrinae", "habitat": "0 -1 -1", "endanger_status": "LC", "population_trend": "Stable", "average_size": 24, "picture_url": "https://www.fishbase.de/images/species/Absor_u0.jpg", "description": "Inhabit rocky lagoons, reef flat shorelines and piers subject to mild surge; juveniles are common in tide pools (Ref. 9710). Benthopelagic (Ref. 58302). Occasionally form schools. Feed on algae, crustaceans and other invertebrates during the day. Oviparous, distinct pairing during breeding (Ref. 205). Eggs are demersal and adhere to the substrate (Ref. 205). Males guard and aerate the eggs (Ref. 205). Highly territorial (Ref. 9710). Utilized as a food fish by the Hawaiians (Ref. 7364).", "speccode": 5689, "catch_year": null, "catch_rate": null, "model": "fish" }, { "id": 8, "scientific_name": "Abudefduf taurus", "common_name": "Night sergeant", "species": "taurus", "genus": "Abudefduf", "family": "Pomacentrinae", "habitat": "0 0 -1", "endanger_status": "LC", "population_trend": "Stable", "average_size": 25, "picture_url": "https://www.fishbase.de/images/species/Abtau_u2.jpg", "description": "Adults inhabit rocky inshore reefs. They prefer wave-cut rock ledges or limestone shorelines and tide pools in regions with surf. Feed mainly on algae but adults also consume Zoanthus and hydroids while juveniles also feed on copepods (Ref. 9626). Oviparous, distinct pairing during breeding (Ref. 205). Eggs are demersal and adhere to the substrate (Ref. 205). Males guard and aerate the eggs (Ref. 205). Marketed fresh (Ref. 3139).", "speccode": 1120, "catch_year": null, "catch_rate": null, "model": "fish" }, { "id": 9, "scientific_name": "Abudefduf troschelii", "common_name": "Panamic sergeant major", "species": "troschelii", "genus": "Abudefduf", "family": "Pomacentrinae", "habitat": "0 0 -1", "endanger_status": "LC", "population_trend": "Unknown", "average_size": 20, "picture_url": "https://www.fishbase.de/images/species/Abtro_u2.jpg", "description": "Adults inhabit rocky and coral reefs (Ref. 9334). Usually in large aggregations. These diurnal feeders feed on plankton at the surface or mid-water; also graze on benthic invertebrates and algae on the reef. Breed during early summer in the Gulf and continues throughout the summer until fall. This fish is a warm-water, stenothermal species. Juveniles of second year class have been observed cleaning schools of striped mullet, halfbeaks and needlefish (Ref. 5592). Oviparous, distinct pairing during breeding (Ref. 205). Eggs are demersal and adhere to the substrate (Ref. 205). Males guard and aerate the eggs (Ref. 205).", "speccode": 8245, "catch_year": null, "catch_rate": null, "model": "fish" }, { "id": 10, "scientific_name": "Abudefduf vaigiensis", "common_name": "Indo-Pacific sergeant", "species": "vaigiensis", "genus": "Abudefduf", "family": "Pomacentrinae", "habitat": "0 0 -1", "endanger_status": "LC", "population_trend": "Stable", "average_size": 20, "picture_url": "https://www.fishbase.de/images/species/Abvai_u9.jpg", "description": "Adults inhabit upper edge of outer reef slopes and inshore rocky reefs. Juveniles associated with drifting seaweed (Ref. 12114, 12115). Benthopelagic (Ref. 58302). Feed on zooplankton, benthic algae, and small invertebrates (Ref. 1602). Often in aggregations (Ref. 9710) feeding at midwater or tending nests among rocks and coral ledges (Ref. 90102). In large numbers at spawning sites that are timed with large tides that carry their pelagic offspring far offshore (Ref. 48636). Oviparous, distinct pairing during breeding (Ref. 205). Eggs are demersal and adhere to the substrate (Ref. 205). Males guard and aerate the eggs (Ref. 205).", "speccode": 6630, "catch_year": null, "catch_rate": null, "model": "fish" } ] }

exec: pm.test("Check Data in Response Body", function () {
pm.test("Check Data in Response Body", function () {

query.description: The population trend you want to filter for

request.description: Filter based on the categories of population trend in one of these categories ['Unknown', 'Stable', 'Increasing', 'Decreasing']

response.name: Get Fish By Population

query.description: The population trend you want to filter for

response.body:
{
    "total_fish_count": 1301,
    "total_fish_returned": 1,
    "data": [
        {
            "id": 1,
            "scientific_name": "Ablennes hians",
            "common_name": "Flat needlefish",
            "species": "hians",
            "genus": "Ablennes",
            "family": "No Family",
            "habitat": "0 -1 -1",
            "endanger_status": "LC",
            "population_trend": "Unknown",
            "average_size": 140,
            "picture_url": "https://www.fishbase.de/images/species/Abhia_m0.jpg",
            "description": "Inhabits neritic and oceanic waters but more often found near islands (Ref. 5213).  Found in estuaries (Ref. 26340), and coastal rivers (Ref. 33587).  Sometimes forming large schools (Ref. 5217).  Feeds mainly on small fishes (Ref. 9279).  Oviparous (Ref. 205).  Eggs may be found attached to objects in the water by filaments on the egg's surface (Ref. 205). Since the jaws are frequently broken, the maximum length is given as body length excluding head and caudal fin.  Usually caught with the help of artificial lights (Ref. 9279).  Marketed  fresh and salted; smoked or frozen (Ref. 9987).  Market limited due to the green-colored flesh (Ref. 5217).  In females, only left gonad is developed, and in males the right gonad is small or absent (Ref. 26938).",
            "speccode": 972,
            "catch_year": "2018",
            "catch_rate": 22,
            "model": "fish"
        }
    ]
}

exec: pm.test("Check Data in Response Body", function () {
pm.test("Check Data in Response Body", function () {

query.description: the attribute you want to sort by
ascending option for sorting (true by default)

request.description:
For fish we can sort by
  • common_name
  • genus
  • species
  • status
  • average_size
For fish we can filter by
  • common_name
  • population_trend (['Unknown', 'Stable', 'Increasing', 'Decreasing']
  • genus
  • status (['DD', 'LC', 'NT', 'VU', 'EN', 'CR', 'EW', 'EX'])
  • family
  • habitat (String of 3 numbers)
    • -1 0 0: Freshwater fish
    • 0 -1 0: Brackish fish
    • 0 0 -1: Saltwater fish
    • Can be a combination of those values to show it lives in more than one type of water ex: -1 -1 0 means found in both fresh and brackish water

response.name: Get Fish with Sort and Filter

query.description: the attribute you want to sort by
ascending option for sorting (true by default)
combining sort and filter
maximum number of fish to return

response.body: { "total_fish_count": 1301, "total_fish_returned": 10, "data": [ { "id": 418, "scientific_name": "Centropyge abei", "common_name": "Abe's angelfish", "species": "abei", "genus": "Centropyge", "family": "No Family", "habitat": "0 0 -1", "endanger_status": "LC", "population_trend": "Stable", "average_size": 9, "picture_url": "https://www.fishbase.de/images/species/Ceabe_u0.jpg", "description": "Found over bottom that is primarily composed of variably sized rubble, with temperature 20-21°C (Ref. 77035).", "speccode": 64214, "catch_year": null, "catch_rate": null, "model": "fish" }, { "id": 169, "scientific_name": "Apterichtus ansp", "common_name": "Academy eel", "species": "ansp", "genus": "Apterichtus", "family": "Ophichthinae", "habitat": "0 0 -1", "endanger_status": "LC", "population_trend": "Unknown", "average_size": 54, "picture_url": "https://www.fishbase.de/images/species/Apans_u0.gif", "description": "Burrows in sand in surf areas.", "speccode": 2635, "catch_year": null, "catch_rate": null, "model": "fish" }, { "id": 21, "scientific_name": "Acanthurus achilles", "common_name": "Achilles tang", "species": "achilles", "genus": "Acanthurus", "family": "Acanthurinae", "habitat": "0 0 -1", "endanger_status": "LC", "population_trend": "Stable", "average_size": 24, "picture_url": "https://www.fishbase.de/images/species/Acach_u8.jpg", "description": "Occurs in clear seaward reefs, usually in groups (Ref. 9710). Benthopelagic (Ref. 58302). Feeds on filamentous and small fleshy algae (Ref. 9267). Monogamous (Ref. 52884). Spine in caudal peduncle may be venomous. Size of metamorphosis from postlarva stage to juvenile is 6 cm (Ref. 9267). This species sometimes hybridizes with A. nigricans (Ref. 9808).", "speccode": 4306, "catch_year": null, "catch_rate": null, "model": "fish" }, { "id": 620, "scientific_name": "Coris gaimard", "common_name": "African coris", "species": "gaimard", "genus": "Coris", "family": "Corinae", "habitat": "0 0 -1", "endanger_status": "LC", "population_trend": "Stable", "average_size": 40, "picture_url": "https://www.fishbase.de/images/species/Cogai_u0.jpg", "description": "A solitary species (Ref. 90102) found in areas of mixed coral, sand and rubble of exposed outer reef flats, lagoon and seaward reefs (Ref. 1602, 48636). Benthopelagic (Ref. 58302). Feeds mainly on mollusks, crabs, and hermit crabs, and occasionally on tunicates and forams (Ref. 1602).", "speccode": 5625, "catch_year": null, "catch_rate": null, "model": "fish" }, { "id": 61, "scientific_name": "Alectis ciliaris", "common_name": "African pompano", "species": "ciliaris", "genus": "Alectis", "family": "Caranginae", "habitat": "0 0 -1", "endanger_status": "LC", "population_trend": "Unknown", "average_size": 150, "picture_url": "https://www.fishbase.de/images/species/Alcil_u7.jpg", "description": "Pelagic in neritic and oceanic waters, sometimes near the bottom (Ref. 5217, 58302). Small juveniles may be found near the shore (Ref. 5217); adults near bottom to depths of 60 m (Ref. 26938). Feed on sedentary or slow moving crustaceans and occasionally feed on small crabs and fishes (Ref. 9283). Juveniles are attractive aquarium fish, but do not do well in captivity (Ref. 12484). Excellent food fish (Ref. 9626); marketed fresh or dried or salted (Ref. 9283).", "speccode": 988, "catch_year": "2018", "catch_rate": 5, "model": "fish" }, { "id": 110, "scientific_name": "Anarchias allardicei", "common_name": "Allardice's moray", "species": "allardicei", "genus": "Anarchias", "family": "Uropterygiinae", "habitat": "0 0 -1", "endanger_status": "LC", "population_trend": "Unknown", "average_size": 17, "picture_url": "https://www.fishbase.de/images/species/Anall_f0.jpg", "description": "Inhabits the interstices of the reef. Benthic (Ref. 58302).", "speccode": 6483, "catch_year": null, "catch_rate": null, "model": "fish" }, { "id": 1060, "scientific_name": "Labropsis alleni", "common_name": "Allen's tubelip", "species": "alleni", "genus": "Labropsis", "family": "No Family", "habitat": "0 0 -1", "endanger_status": "LC", "population_trend": "Unknown", "average_size": 10, "picture_url": "https://www.fishbase.de/images/species/Laall_u0.jpg", "description": "Occurs in lagoon and seaward reefs, in areas with dense coral growth (Ref. 9710) and on steep slopes, solitary or in pairs (Ref. 90102). Probably feeds on coral polyps (Ref. 6023). Juveniles clean other fishes.", "speccode": 4863, "catch_year": null, "catch_rate": null, "model": "fish" }, { "id": 707, "scientific_name": "Decapterus muroadsi", "common_name": "Amberstripe scad", "species": "muroadsi", "genus": "Decapterus", "family": "Caranginae", "habitat": "0 0 -1", "endanger_status": "LC", "population_trend": "Unknown", "average_size": 50, "picture_url": "https://www.fishbase.de/images/species/Demur_u3.jpg", "description": "Adults are pelagic (Ref. 58302), in oceanic and inshore waters (Ref. 9563) forming schools (Ref. 9283). They feed mainly on planktonic invertebrates (Ref. 9283). Marketed fresh and salted or dried (Ref. 9283).", "speccode": 12302, "catch_year": null, "catch_rate": null, "model": "fish" }, { "id": 552, "scientific_name": "Chromis amboinensis", "common_name": "Ambon chromis", "species": "amboinensis", "genus": "Chromis", "family": "Pomacentrinae", "habitat": "0 0 -1", "endanger_status": "LC", "population_trend": "Stable", "average_size": 10, "picture_url": "https://www.fishbase.de/images/species/Chamb_u3.jpg", "description": "Adults inhabit coral-rich areas of clear lagoon and seaward reefs. Abundant on steep outer reef slopes below 24 m, uncommon in lagoons. Juveniles in large branching corals, adults mainly in caves (Ref. 48636). Found in aggregations (Ref. 9710). Diurnal species (Ref. 54980; 113699). Oviparous, distinct pairing during breeding (Ref. 205). Eggs are demersal and adhere to the substrate (Ref. 205). Males guard and aerate the eggs (Ref. 205).", "speccode": 5671, "catch_year": null, "catch_rate": null, "model": "fish" }, { "id": 606, "scientific_name": "Conger oceanicus", "common_name": "American conger", "species": "oceanicus", "genus": "Conger", "family": "Congrinae", "habitat": "0 0 -1", "endanger_status": "LC", "population_trend": "Unknown", "average_size": 230, "picture_url": "https://www.fishbase.de/images/species/Cooce_u0.jpg", "description": "Occurs from shallow inshore waters to depths of 477 m and up to 260 m in the Gulf of Maine (Ref. 7135). Benthic (Ref. 5951). Nocturnal predators (Ref. 93252). Feeds mainly on fishes, but also on shrimps and small shellfish. Commonly caught by anglers along piers, docks and jetties in middle Atlantic states.", "speccode": 300, "catch_year": "2018", "catch_rate": 40, "model": "fish" } ] }

item.description:
Fish related queries/request

**Description of Return Types**

"total_fish_count" = total number of fishes in database

"total_fish_returned" = total number of instances returned

"id" = the id of the fish

"scientific_name" = scientific name of the fish,

"common_name" = common name of the fish

"species" = specie of the fish

"genus" = genus of the fish

"family" = family of the fish

"habitat" = String of 3 numbers:
           (-1 0 0: Freshwater fish)
           ( 0 -1 0: Brackish fish)
           (0 0 -1: Saltwater fish)
           (Can be a combination of those values to show it lives in more than one type of water)
           ie: "0 -1 -1" (means both brackish and saltwater)

"endanger_status" = endanger status given by IUCN, look below for more information

"population_trend" = Unknown, Stable, Increasing, Decreasing

"average_size" = average size of the fish in meters

"picture_url" = url to the picture of the fish

"description": = short description of the fish,

"speccode": = code to identify the fish (used for backend purpose)

"catch_year" = year the catch rate data was recorded

"catch_rate" = catch rate of fish (total landings) 

"location" = array of location ids that are related to this fish

"human_impact_ids" = dictionary of arrays of ids that are related to fish.

For water we can filter by

  • size (size_min and size_max)

item.description:
Water related queries/request

**Description of Return Types**

"total_water_count" = Total number of bodies of water in the database

"total_water_returned" = Total number of bodies of water returned in this query

"data" = Block for the list of water entries

"id" = Id entry in the database

"name" = Name of the body of water

"type" = Type of body of water returned

"latitude" = Rough latitude value of the body of water

"longitude" = Rough longitude value of the body of water

"min_latitude" = Rough latitude value of the body of water, offset to -latitude

"min_longitude" = Rough longitude value of the body of water, offset to -longitude

"max_latitude" = Rough latitude value of the body of water, offset to +latitude

"max_longitude" = Rough longitude value of the body of water, offset to +longitude

"water_temp" = Water temperature of the body of water

"windspeedkmph" = Current wind speed of the water in KMPH, if applicable

"size" = Surface area of the body of water, in mi^2

"fish" = List of Id's of fish found in the body of water

"human_impact_ids" = List of Id's of human impact that affects this body of water

item.name: Human Impact

exec: pm.test("Check Keys in Response Body", function () {
pm.test("Check Data in Response Body", function () {

query.description: Maximum number of entries to return
Index to start querying at

request.description: Returns all the human impact instances we have avaliable.

response.name: Get all Human Impacts

query.description: Maximum number of entries to return
Index to start querying at

response.body:
{
    "total_impact_count": 110,
    "total_impact_returned": 2,
    "data": [
        {
            "id": 4,
            "category": "pollution",
            "subcategory": "tanker_oil_spills",
            "latitude": 51.6796,
            "longitude": -5.1777,
            "date": "15/02/1996",
            "description": "The oil tanker SEA EMPRESS, carrying 130,000 tonnes of Forties Blend North Sea crude oil, ran aground in the entrance to Milford Haven, South-West Wales on the evening of 15th February 1996. Although the tanker was refloated within a couple of hours, it sustained serious damage to its starboard and centre tanks, resulting in a massive release of oil. Attempts to bring the vessel under control and to undertake a ship-to-ship transfer operation were thwarted by severe weather and the tanker grounded and refloated several more times over a period of five days. In all, some 72,000 tonnes of crude oil and 370 tonnes of heavy fuel oil were released into the sea between the initial grounding and the final refloating operation.",

            "date": "20/04/2010",
            "description": "The largest accidental oil spill was recorded in the Gulf of Mexico in 2010. On 20 April, an explosion at the Deepwater Horizon offshore drilling rig caused oil to gush from the sea-floor 5,000ft below. The blast itself killed 11 workers on the platform and injured 17 others. The leak was finally brought under control three months later by capping the wellhead, but only after it had released around 210 million gallons into the sea. The oil spill caused extensive damage to marine ecosystems and severely disrupted the Gulf’s fishing and tourism industries. In an attempt to protect US coasts, authorities used skimmer ships, floating containment booms, anchored barriers and sandbags along the shoreline. Investigations later revealed that the cement pumped in to seal BP’s Macondo Well a day before the explosion was not given enough time to set properly, and that two safety defences subsequently failed. A witness report by oil-field cementing expert Glen Benge said: “The BP engineers chose to accept additional risks when designing the cement job with the awareness that remedial cementing work could be done at a later date.”",

item.name: Get Human Impact with Sort and Filter

exec: pm.test("Check Data in Response Body", function () {
pm.test("Check Keys in Response Body", function () {

query.description: The attribute you want to sort by
Ascending option for sorting (true by default)
The subcategory of human impact to return
Maximum number of entries to return

request.description:
For impact we can sort by
  • name
  • long
  • lat
  • subcategory
  • count_density_1
All the ones with numeric ranges you need to specify both a maximum and maximum for the api call. The names of the min and max are listed below.
For impact we can filter by
  • subcategory
  • long (long_min and long_max)
  • lat (lat_min and lat_max)
  • CD_1 (CD_1_min and CD_1_max)
  • oil_amount (oil_amount_min and oil_amount_max)

response.name: Get Human Impact with Sort and Filter

query.description: The attribute you want to sort by
Ascending option for sorting (true by default)
The subcategory of human impact to return
Maximum number of entries to return

response.body:
{
    "total_impact_count": 110,
    "total_impact_returned": 1,
    "data": [
        {
            "id": 3,
            "category": "pollution",
            "subcategory": "tanker_oil_spills",
            "latitude": 59.8049,
            "longitude": -1.1411,
            "date": "05/01/1993",
            "description": "Following engine failure, BRAER ran aground in severe weather conditions on Garth's Ness, Shetland on 5th January 1993. Over a period of 12 days the entire cargo of 84,700 tonnes of Norwegian Gullfaks crude oil, plus up to 1,500 tonnes of heavy bunker oil, were lost as almost constant storm force winds and heavy seas broke the ship apart. Weather conditions prevented the use of mechanical recovery equipment at sea, although about 130 tonnes of chemical dispersant was applied from aircraft during periods when the wind abated slightly and some oil remained on the surface. Oiling of shorelines was minimal relative to the size of the spill and cleanup involved the collection of oily debris and seaweed by a small workforce. The BRAER spill was very unusual in that a surface slick was not produced. A combination of the light nature of the oil and the exceptionally strong wind and wave energy naturally dispersed the oil throughout the water column. The oil droplets were adsorbed onto sediment particles which eventually sank to the sea bed. Sub-surface currents led to this oil being spread over a very wide area, although a significant portion eventually ended up in two deep, fine sediment 'sinks'. A wide range of fish and shellfish over a fairly large area became contaminated with oil, resulting in the imposition of a Fisheries Exclusion Zone. Farmed salmon held in sea cages in the surface waters within this zone bore the brunt of the contamination since they could not escape the cloud of dispersed oil. Although this contamination was lost quickly once clean water conditions returned, millions of salmon that could not be marketed had to be destroyed. The Exclusion Zone was progressively lifted as fish and shellfish species were found by chemical analysis and taste testing to be free of contamination, although it was still in place over 6 years after the spill for mussels and Norway lobsters at some sites within the closure area. The BRAER spill was unusual in that a significant amount of oil was blown on to land adjacent to the wreck site. The effects of this airborne oil were localised and had no more than a temporary impact on vegetation and livestock. Seabird casualties were also relatively low. Considering the size of the spill, the environmental impacts were surprisingly limited.",
            "name": "Braer",
            "oil_amount": 85000,
            "count_density_1": null,
            "count_density_2": null,
            "count_density_3": null,
            "count_density_4": null,
            "plant_rating": null,
            "plant_location": null,
            "plant_water_source": null,
            "locationname": ", Scotland",
            "imageurl": "https://tse4.mm.bing.net/th?id=OIP.ZXmCFfM8F2PeVvqqgnV0HQHaE7&pid=Api",
            "model": "human_impact"
        }
    ]
}

item.description:
Contains Human Impact/Effect Related requests/queries

**Description of Return Types**

"total_impact_count" = total number of human impacts in database

"total_impact_returned" = total number of instances returned

"id" = the id of the impact

"category" = category of the impact

"subcategory" = subcategory of the impact

"latitude" = latitude coordinate of impact

"longitude" = longitude coordinate of impact

"date" = date impact occurred

"description" = description of impact

"name" = name associated with impact

"oil amount" = amount of oil spilled (if applicable)

"count_density_1" = density of 0.33-1.00mm sized plastic pieces

"count_density_2" = density of 1.01-4.75mm sized plastic pieces

"count_density_3" = density of 4.76-200mm sized plastic pieces

"count_density_4" = density of 200+mm sized plastic pieces

"plant_rating" = rating for the power plant

"plant_location": = location of power plant

"plant_water_source": = water source of power plant

"catch_year" = year the catch rate data was recorded

"location" = array of location ids that are related to this impact

"fish" = array of fish ids that are related to impact
